author: radekkapka
content:
Hey, I know I am jumping ahead but I would like to add something to what I said at ACDC, which was that saving Holesky with mass slashings won't be applicable to Mainnet. I still stand by this because I can't imagine that everyone will just allow themselves to be slashed, but what can potentially happen in such a case? Either (1) the majority will be on a "bugged" chain, that chain will finalize and become the de facto canonical chain, or (2) the chain will collapse and will need a social intervention. Even if (1) happens there is a possibility that the bug will cause further technical/security consequences and will require a social intervention anyhow. Another point is that no matter how many devnets we spin up, each with a different failure scenario, there is always a non-zero possibility that something that we are not prepared for will fail on Mainnet.

All that leads me to believing we should have a nuclear option, which is a social intervention process. Now I have no idea how would the ideal process look like, but what came to my mind today is the following. Each fork has two steps: a justified step and a finalized step. The fork epoch that we currently use marks the justified step. From that point on we wait 24 hours and if the chain is stable (or stable enough) we mark the fork as finalized and continue as usual. However if we face an issue such as the current one, we roll back the last 24 hours as if the fork never happened and reschedule the fork to a later date. I expect 99.99% of critical errors will happen at the first few epochs of a fork, so waiting 24 hours should be more than enough. Of course there is no math behind this number, it just feels right to me (similarly how we wait 24 hours now before applying slashings). Since fork times are declared way in advance, users can prepare mentally for such a scenario.

Do I like having this nuclear option? No. But I prefer it over a massive panic both here and on the user side.
